summary: Anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC) is an aggressive and uncommon form of thyroid cancer characterized by the uncontrolled growth of highly abnormal cells in the thyroid gland. It accounts for a small percentage of thyroid cancer cases but is responsible for a disproportionately high number of deaths due to its aggressive behavior and resistance to treatments. ATC often dedifferentiates from pre-existing differentiated thyroid cancer, leading to poor prognosis and a median survival time of a few months.
risk_factors: Repeated radiation exposure to the chest or neck
Exposure to radiation treatments to head or neck as a child
Certain genetic conditions (e.g., multiple endocrine neoplasia)
Family history of thyroid cancer or thyroid disease
symptoms: Redness and swelling of overlying skin
Symptoms from distant metastases (e.g., to the brain)
diagnosis: Immunohistochemistry testing (keratin, p53, PAX8 positive; thyroid transcription factor-1, thyroglobulin, calcitonin negative)
Physical exam (checking neck for swelling, lumps)
Ultrasound imaging (hypoechoic mass with invasion of local structures)
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the neck (if surgery planned)
CT scan of neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis (if PET unavailable)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain (to assess for distant metastases)
treatments: Targeted therapy (e.g., BRAF and MEK inhibitors like dabrafenib and trametinib, vemurafenib and cobimetinib)
